p: Beatrice Giglio is an EPSRC Research Fellow in the Department of Statistics of Warwick University; she is pursuing her Ph.D. in statistics in the same department under Prof. Wynn's supervision. She received her M.Sc. (1996) in statistics and applied stochastic systems at the University College London, and her Laurea in mathematics (1993) summa cum laude at Università degli Studi di Perugia, Italy.

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Stat., Warwick Univ., Coventry, UK
authors.name: B. Giglio

p: Daniel Q. Naiman is Professor in the Department of Mathematical Sciences at the Johns Hopkins University. He received a Bachelors degree (1977) summa cum laude from Cornell University (majoring in mathematics), and a Ph.D. (1982) from the University of Illinois at Urbana in the Mathematics Department. He is an Associate Editor for J. Computational and Graphical Statistics and member of several professional societies such as the American Mathematical Society, the American Statistical Association, and the Bernoulli Society. He was elected a Fellow (1997) of the Institute of Mathematical Statistics.

Henry P. Wynn has been at Warwick University since 1995 as a Professor of Industrial Statistics, and is Chairman of the Risk Initiative and Statistical Consultancy Unit, a group funded by a range of UK and EU research grants together with a consultancy function. He has an M.A. in honors mathematics from the University of Oxford and a Ph.D. (1970) in mathematical statistics from Imperial College. He has an international reputation in theoretical and applied statistics with about 130 published papers and 3 books. He holds the Guy medal in Silver from the Royal Statistical Society and fellowships of several international organizations.

details.abstract: There is a close mathematical relationship between integer grids of a particular echelon form and coherent systems in reliability in the case of states coded as integer grid points. This paper shows that such an integer representation is the link between abstract tube theory, which gives improved inclusion-exclusion bounds, and an algebraic method, Grobner bases, based on the polynomial ideal of the failure event.
